title: Chronic Otitis Media with Bilateral Mastoidectomies
chief_complaint: My hearing fluctuates; sometimes it seems near normal, but other times it creates severe problems in communication.

problem_summary.course: Fluctuating hearing loss with constant drainage.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Strong pungent odor near ears; constant drainage.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Severe problems in communication; unable to use air-conduction hearing aid due to drainage.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Patient has been told nothing can be done, but previous hearing aid attempt failed due to drainage.

history.present_illness: Patient reports lifelong ear infections and fluctuating hearing. A strong pungent odor is noticeable near her ears.
history.otologic_history: Bilateral mastoidectomies. History of constant drainage.
history.medical_psych_history: Family doctor has prescribed renewable eardrops and stated nothing can be done to improve hearing.
history.prior_management: Tried a hearing aid in the right ear, but constant drainage made use impossible; the aid was subsequently lost.
history.patient_goals: Determine if hearing can be improved despite previous advice.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral mixed hearing loss. Air-conduction thresholds are essentially flat around 40-50 dB HL. Bone-conduction thresholds indicate good cochlear reserve in the low/mid frequencies (0-10 dB HL) dropping in the high frequencies (30-40 dB HL at 4000 Hz). Significant air-bone gaps present bilaterally.

numeric_results.BC_Thresholds: 0-10 dB HL at 500-1000 Hz, sloping to ~35-40 dB HL at 4000 Hz

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRT aligns with pure-tone averages. Word recognition scores (SRS) are excellent bilaterally.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Unable to obtain a seal in either ear, consistent with patent perforations or open mastoid cavities.

numeric_results.Note: NO SEAL OBTAINABLE written on tympanogram

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: All waves prolonged absolute latencies, but interpeak latencies and latency-intensity functions are normal. This pattern is consistent with conductive hearing loss.

tests.name: Tone decay test
tests.key_findings: Negative for retrocochlear pathology at 4000 Hz.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a bilateral mixed hearing loss, predominantly conductive in nature, with significant air-bone gaps and excellent speech recognition scores. The sensorineural component is mild to moderate in the high frequencies. Immittance testing could not be completed due to inability to obtain a seal, likely due to tympanic membrane perforations or mastoid cavities. ABR results support a conductive etiology (prolonged absolute latencies with normal interpeaks).
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows a 'mixed' hearing loss, meaning there is a problem with how sound gets to the inner ear (conductive) and a smaller issue with the inner ear itself.
The good news is your ability to understand speech is excellent when sounds are loud enough.

The strong odor and drainage you described are concerning for an active infection or cholesteatoma. It is critical that you see an Ear, Nose, and Throat specialist (Otologist) for a second opinion immediately.

Contrary to what you were told, there are options to help you hear. If the drainage persists, we can consider a bone-conduction hearing aid, which bypasses the ear canal entirely and won't be damaged by drainage.
Do not give up hope; we need to address the medical health of your ears first, then we can address the hearing.
notes_for_actor: Portray a 16-year-old who is frustrated and resigned because a doctor told her 'nothing can be done'.
You should mention the smell/odor yourself or react with embarrassment if the clinician notices it.
Emphasize that the previous hearing aid was gross/wet from drainage and you lost it.
